awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Artificial intelligence-based software package for end-to-end structural health monitoring of infrastructure systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technology that uses the internet-of-things and/or fiber optic-based monitoring systems to solve problems faced by structural health monitoring companies related to data processing, interpretation, and storage. During its service life, civil infrastructure should satisfy the requirement of safety and sustainability for the designated operation. However, due to natural disasters and extreme events (such as strong winds and earthquakes), structures degrade in performance over time, or they get damaged severely and even collapse. For example, America's Infrastructure received an overall grade of C- according to the American Society of Civil Engineers Report Card 2021, indicating that the nation's infrastructure is in mediocre condition, has deficiencies, and needs attention. Structural health monitoring systems have gained rapid popularity in providing real-time information for the safety assessment of structures. However, structural health monitoring companies worldwide are facing challenges in data processing, interpretation, and storage, which limits their ability to obtain sufficiently comprehensive information about the health of infrastructure asset that is being monitored.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of smart and effective data processing, interpretation, and storage in the structural health monitoring systems using conventional artificial intelligence and computational intelligence. Conventional artificial intelligence in this technology will describe the problem and build logical reasoning using explicit rules.  Computational intelligence, which comprises an interconnected network of simple units, will be used to acquire information about the output from specific input data. The novelty of this innovation includes the development of a hybrid system by incorporating new techniques from both conventional artificial intelligence and computational intelligence to automatically accomplish the process of data acquisition and data analysis. A provision of cloud services in the core technology is used to store data before and after analysis and evaluation for further processing. Finally, this technology will interpret analyzed data to detect and locate damages and make decisions on the deterioration level of an infrastructure asset.  This will allow the system to determine the required actions before danger occurs. This technology will provide an effective way for data processing, interpretation, and storage in monitoring systems in real-time by dividing the processes into three main components, namely checking for plausibility, short-term data analysis, and long-term data analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Overview

This project focused on advancing structural health monitoring (SHM) of infrastructure systems by conceptualizing an artificial intelligence-based software package tailored to the unique challenges of high-rise buildings and bridges. The primary goal was to address critical gaps in current SHM practices, including inefficiencies in data processing, high implementation costs, and limited accessibility for many stakeholders. By prioritizing customer needs and market demands, the project aimed to pave the way for a solution that enhances infrastructure safety, extends service life, and promotes long-term sustainability.

Through extensive stakeholder engagement and market research, the project provided valuable insights into the needs of SHM professionals and decision-makers. This understanding has informed the framework for an innovative, adaptable software solution designed to optimize monitoring practices, improve decision-making, and address pressing issues in the management of critical infrastructure. The work accomplished lays a strong foundation for future advancements in SHM, even as the project concludes its scope.

Key Outcomes

The project achieved significant progress in understanding the challenges and opportunities in the SHM market, focusing on high-rise buildings and bridges. Key accomplishments include:

  • Conducted 126 interviews with stakeholders, including structural engineers and industry leaders, providing critical insights into customer needs and market demands. High-rise buildings emerged as a key focus due to their vulnerability to disasters, maintenance demands, and safety concerns. The interviews highlighted industry pain points, such as high costs and inefficiencies in data analysis, shaping the project’s direction.
  • Refined the Business Model Canvas (BMC) iteratively, focusing on affordability, efficiency, and user-friendliness. Structural engineers and SHM companies managing high-rise infrastructure were identified as primary users. The model emphasized adaptability and cost-effectiveness to address broader use cases.
  • Developed a conceptual framework for a minimum viable product (MVP) with features like real-time data visualization and predictive analytics. Although not yet complete, this groundwork provides a strong starting point for addressing inefficiencies in SHM practices and improving decision-making.
  • Pivoted to prioritize high-rise buildings due to their unique challenges while recognizing potential applications in bridges and industrial infrastructure. This strategic focus ensures scalability and relevance across various infrastructure types.
  • Participated in major events, such as American Concrete Institute (ACI) conventions and the Precast Concrete Tradeshow, fostering connections with experts and potential customers. These engagements laid the foundation for potential future partnerships and field testing.
  • Identified barriers such as resistance to workflow changes and implementation costs. These findings have informed strategies for outreach and education to promote adoption of SHM technologies in future phases.

These outcomes provide a strong foundation for advancing SHM practices, improving infrastructure resilience, and addressing key industry challenges.

Broader Impacts

This project has significant implications for society, infrastructure resilience, and sustainability, addressing critical challenges in SHM. By advancing SHM practices, the project contributes to the following:

  • Enhanced monitoring capabilities improve the ability to detect structural issues early, reducing the risk of catastrophic failures. This not only protects lives but also minimizes the social and economic disruptions caused by infrastructure failures.
  • By extending the service life of critical infrastructure, the project reduces material waste and promotes the efficient use of construction resources. This approach supports environmentally responsible practices and aligns with global goals for sustainable development.
  • Timely maintenance and early detection of issues help infrastructure managers avoid costly repairs and replacements. This proactive approach reduces long-term costs while ensuring the continued reliability and functionality of vital infrastructure.

These impacts extend beyond the technical realm, fostering safer, more sustainable, and economically efficient infrastructure systems that benefit communities and society at large.

Professional Development

This project offered team members valuable opportunities for professional growth, equipping them with essential skills and experiences that extend beyond the technical scope of the work:

  • Gained hands-on experience in customer engagement, market analysis, and stakeholder communication, refining their ability to identify and address real-world challenges.
  • Built strong industry connections through networking at key events such as the ACI conventions and the Precast Concrete Tradeshow, enhancing their understanding of industry trends and needs.
  • Developed a deeper appreciation for the integration of technical innovation with market application, bridging the gap between engineering research and practical implementation.

Conclusion

This project has successfully addressed critical challenges in the SHM industry by identifying key market needs, refining business strategies, and laying the groundwork for an innovative AI-driven solution. Through extensive customer engagement, market analysis, and professional development opportunities, the project has built a strong foundation for advancing SHM practices and enhancing infrastructure resilience, sustainability, and safety. While the software solution is not yet market-ready, the insights gained, and frameworks developed provide a clear roadmap for future development and commercialization. The project aims to contribute to public safety, minimize economic losses, and support sustainable infrastructure management practices alongside its technical advancements.


Last Modified: 01/30/2025
Modified by: Togay Ozbakkaloglu
